text_clean:
Ohio has a long-standing aerospace legacy, beginning with the world’s first aircraft factory and continuing through its role as a hub for advanced air mobility (AAM) development. Dayton, Ohio, is central to this history: the Wright brothers refined powered flight there, and the city is now home to major eVTOL manufacturing activity. In 2023, Joby Aviation announced plans for its first scaled manufacturing facility in Dayton; in early 2025, it confirmed the acquisition of a more than 700,000-square-foot facility in the same region. This second facility will initially support production of four aircraft per month by 2027, with operations beginning in 2025, and complements Joby’s existing manufacturing footprint in California and Ohio. The expansion reflects Ohio’s growing position as a national center for eVTOL aircraft manufacturing and addresses a key bottleneck in the AAM sector—scaling manufacturing for commercialisation.

JobsOhio, Ohio’s private, nonprofit economic development organisation, supports this growth through a funding model that reinvests approximately $450 million annually in economic development initiatives, sourced from profits generated by Ohio’s state-controlled liquor distribution system. JobsOhio customises each investment to deliver measurable returns for Ohio, primarily through job creation and payroll tax generation, with an average break-even period of under two years across more than 4,000 deals. Workforce development is a core component of nearly every JobsOhio agreement, including customised training programmes, partnerships with community colleges and universities, and a relocation incentive programme that reimburses up to $15,000 per worker—and up to $250,000 per company—for individuals relocating to Ohio in 71 critical disciplines. Ohio graduates over 100,000 STEM students annually and maintains a dense network of universities, technical colleges, and job centres.

Ohio’s aerospace ecosystem benefits from geographic and institutional integration. Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, the largest single-site employer in the state, hosts the Air Force Research Laboratory and the National Air and Space Intelligence Center. The National Advanced Air Mobility Center of Excellence in Springfield provides a permissive testing environment for drones and eVTOL aircraft through early Federal Aviation Administration engagement, allowing manufacturers to test without individual FAA waivers. BETA Technologies completed a flight demonstration with its ALIA CTOL aircraft at The Ohio State University’s airport in August 2024. Ohio is the top supplier state to both Boeing and Airbus, and companies operating in the state—including Joby Aviation—leverage both the Springfield test corridor and collaboration with the Air Force Research Laboratory. Joby plans to employ up to 2,000 people near Dayton for production alone.

JobsOhio has designated advanced aerospace and defence as one of its “Super Sectors”, reflecting convergence among legacy aerospace, advanced manufacturing, autonomy, propulsion, and defence. GE Aerospace, headquartered in Ohio, contributes to propulsion innovation, while Hartzell Propeller—founded with roots tracing to the Wright brothers—now produces components for eVTOL aircraft. The U.S. Department of Transportation’s national AAM strategy and the FAA’s planned eVTOL Integration Pilot Program in 2026 are expected to accelerate operational deployment nationwide, and Ohio aims to serve as a proving ground for these frameworks. JobsOhio reports increased deal activity in the last two quarters of 2025. Ohio positions itself as a location where companies can identify requirements, develop technology, test aircraft, and manufacture at scale—all within close proximity and at competitive cost—supported by a skilled workforce and high quality of life.
reason: 文本未提及任何上述指标中所要求的明确事件或数值。例如，关于FAA TIA 'For-Credit'测试（指标1和6），文中未说明FAA试飞员是否已开始计分飞行，也未出现‘Progressing towards’等降级措辞；关于FAA Stage 4审核进度（指标2和7），文中未提供任何完成度百分比数据；关于迪拜基建与售票许可（指标3和8），未提及相关内容；关于Toyota制造联盟协议及资金（指标4），未提及协议签署或二期资金到账；关于FAA-Conforming机队数量（指标5），虽提到Joby在Dayton建厂并计划生产，但未披露具体符合性飞机数量的净增长；关于Archer诉讼案（指标9）和现金流恶化（指标10），文中均无相关信息。因此，没有任何一条指标被满足。
